reviewText:
I bought Worms World Party Remastered because I need to own every Worms game.
Worms 2 and Armageddon are my favourite Worms games and I figured since WWP was remastered it would be my new go to Worms game since it was the last of that group of games.

I prefer the older style of game play rather than the new Worms games especially because of what they did to the ninja rope!

I thought since they had delays releasing the game that it was going to be impressive but I was mistaken.

To start off you load the game and you have the old 4:3 menus stretched to whatever screen size you have, mine is 16:9. It could be because of my graphics drivers but I don't have this issue with other games.
The mouse cursor still tracks like it is on a 4:3 screen so moving up and down is normal but left and right movements of the cursor are just too fast.

I have 3 screens and WWP was playing in the centre screen.
Now the game menu runs in psudeo full screen which caused some issues.
When you move the mouse to the left or right of the game window you actually scroll on to the other screens that arent used in the game. You try to move the cursor back to the game screen and it sometimes blocks the cursor leaving it on the unused screen.
I had to move the cursor back and forth a few times and it eventually went back to the game screen. N.B. because the left and right scroll is accelerated due to the 4:3 stretch you can get the cursor to the middle screen but I actually had the cursor go from my left screen, past the WWP screen in the middle, and to my right screen because the cursor was so fast in the game screen.

Starting a game is just like it used to be on the original WWP but the stretched menus just don't look nice.

Once in a game it played just like it used to.
The updated sounds were nice but just didn't match the graphics.
The graphics are the same as the original WWP and the old soundbanks just fit better.
Moving the cursor off the screen isn't a problem during a game since moving the mouse will just move the camera or weapon selection cursor.

The game defaulted to my 2560x1440 graphics but the game didn't run like it was 60FPS.
It was a bit choppy and just seemed dated.
I quit the match changed the graphics to 1680x1050.
I loaded a match and it was smooth but still looked the same as WWP back in the day.
I quit WWP completely and saw that because I changed the game resolution to a lower resolution than my 2560x1440 desktop it had shifted all of my cursors that were on the lower part of the desktop up higher!
Luckily I have DesktopOK running so I can just restore the icons to their original positions easily but this is just rediculous.

This game was a rushed port, which is odd since they had delays, and I recommend only die hard Worms fans purchase it.

I didn't try online play and only had a quick few test solo games and it plays ok in lower resolutions but the implimentation of the game seems like it's still designed for Windows 95/98 or XP.

One other issue that I encountered was loading the game.
If you load the game and in the part with the developer Team 17 and Tick Tock names appear you click on a different screen the game screen will minimize but you can't restore it.
Alt-Tab doesn't show the game is running and I had to kill W2.exe with task manager to quit and then I reloaded the game.

There's just too many issues with the game and I think it should have been redesigned for Windows 7/8/10 not just ported like this.

Team 17 please release some major patches to fix everything that is broken so we can enjoy this game on our new computers without these issues.

Worms World Party Remastered is a re-release of the 2001 smash hit, Worms World Party. This game was released in July 2015.  The remastered edition has proven to not be as popular as the predecessors with only 6000 people picking this game up from Steam.

The gameplay of Worms World Party Remastered is essentially the same as the original game. Absolutely everything is the same. The huge selection of weapons in your worm’s arsenal makes a return; the classics are still here such as bazookas and grenades, along with some of the newer weapons such as exploding sheep, homing pigeons and napalm strikes. The game has a single player mode, online multiplayer, and local multiplayer. I only played a couple of matches in the single player mode against the AI, but this proved to be a difficult matter, simply because the AI in this game totally knows how to control their weapons more than me, and can take the wind and other elements into consideration, meaning you'll probably get beaten.

That being said, the multiplayer is where you'll get the most fun out of Worms as you should well know if you played the other games in the series. The online play is broken though, I tried playing and it is a convoluted mess. You have to put in IP addresses of servers, ports, everything that shouldn't be needed to be done in a remastered version of the game - when I finally managed to get it all set up, there was two people playing...two people in the multiplayer side of this game. There was no point me trying to get into the game as they were just sat in their own two separate lobbies themselves.  Where I had the most enjoyment and gameplay was in the local multiplayer playing with my partner.

Before you start a match, you get to create your own team of worms, giving your team a name, then naming all of your individual worms - next you can give your team a style of voice, with a large selection of accents to just from, customize your worms grave stones, and your teams flag. Finally you also get to choose your teams victory" music which plays when you win a match.  The hot potatoes style gameplay of passing the controller between each other works just fine

reviewText:
Is this a good game? Yes.

Should you buy this game? No.

Worms World Party is at it's core, the great 2D Worms game that we have all come to love over the years. It is Worms at it's greatest.

However, this game is being sold under false pretenses. Instead of having the title 'Worms World Party Remastered', it should actually be called 'Worms World Party Steam Edition'. Team 17 have taken Worms World Party and done as little work as possible in order to get it working with modern computers and modern monitors.

The standout improvements to the game are 1080p support, and controller support. The problem is that these are about the only major improvements to this nearly 15 year old game and even those improvements come with caveats. For instance, the 1080p support is only when in game. The main menus have not been improved from the 15 year old game and are extremely low resolution. Controller support feels a bit tacked on as things like scrolling and positioning don't work as well as they should.

It is quite obvious that this is just a port of the original game as many of the limitations of the original are still present. Probably the most egregious of these issues is the way multiplayer is handled. More specifically hosting of multiplayer games. You can't install the game then go straight into hosting multiplayer games. In order to host a game you first need to go into your router and set up port forwarding. You then need to edit the registry and finally you need to enter your WAN IP address into the game. This is unacceptable.

The hosting issue alone has nearly killed the community for this game dead. I have seen the ridiculous situation where there were 10 people in a lobby all wanting to play a multiplayer game but none of them could host a game so no one could play. I ended up writing a Steam guide to try and help people get around this problem.

It is this hosting problem which I think has led to the multiplayer being pretty much dead. The game has only been out for a week and the average player count is 9.5 players per hour (http://steamcharts.com/app/270910). This number is also made up of people playing single player as well. Good luck trying to find a multiplayer game.

Then there is the menus. They look like they are presented in 640x480 resolution and they look dated design wise as well. When in game the resolution is 1080p but the weapon select screen is not scaled properly so is very small and makes it difficult to see what the icons are.

Those are the major issues but there are quite a few other little niggles.

This game is not a remaster. It is a quick cash grab. The original game has had a minimal amount of work done to it to make it compatible with modern computers and that is about it.

We have been complaining to Team 17 on the forums and the Team 17 rep told us he would have a plan of action to present to us in order to improve the game by the end of the week. The end of the week has come and gone with no word from the rep.

I believe it is pretty unlikely that the game will ever be improved as there is no financial incentive for Team 17 to do so. The game is dead on arrival.

Basically I would say to any potential buyers, don't do it. Don't support Team 17 who have taken the good will of their fans for granted for too long. This is a quick cash grab and the game has no future. Don't waste your money or time on this.

First of all before starting this review, I admit I was worried about this port: there was a flood of complains back when this game got out on STEAM with many people complaining the game had many issues. Because of that I was with some doubts if I could get the game or not without fearing of having to ask for a refund. In the end I ended getting this as a gift and I decided to have a look if what people were saying is true. In the startup I did have two issues: the title screen and menu was a bit small with the clouds dragging on the black frame around it. Once I reached the Options screen, the screen went completely black, impossible to see anything. I had to open the task manager of Windows to exit the program. However, once I restarted the game those issues were gone. Since then I tested the game for several hours and I found NO issues anymore. Quick Match, Training, Missions, Deathmatch, Options and Online matches were working 100%. I dunno if I was either lucky or the developers launched patches in the meantime but by my experience with this port I can safely tell people that they can buy with trust.

As for the review, this is a sequel of the best Worms title up to date, Worms Armageddon, using the same game engine. This sequel not only counts with the most positive features of Armageddon but it includes many novelties like Wormapedia, Team Battlefields, Wormpot for random match rules, new missions and a MUCH more complete training campaign, allowing both unnexperienced and experienced players to learn the possibilities and tricks of the game and improve their skills.

The remastered version counts with new sound effects (that are optional to use or not) and a graphically improved menu.

As a personal suggestion, I would like to see the game supporting in future higher resolutions than just Full HD: Armageddon is capable of this.

To keep it short, Worms World Party is an obligatory title to Worms fans to expand even further from the Armageddon universe and to fans of fun and cartoony strategy games. 100% recommended!

reviewText:
This is Worms World Party, just the way I remember it. It's the best Worms game ever made, and, after years of terrible Worms games and 3D, it has aged remarkably well. Running without issues on Windows 10.

It's getting alot of justified criticism due to the word 'Remastered'--it shouldn't be called a remaster, rather a 'Steam edition'. It is false advertising. This is because the game has  is still in the original resolution outside the gameplay, and not much has actually been 'remastered', apart from the gameplay, which is in 1080p and a solid 60fps. It's the same game with more resolution options tacked on and Steamworks support.
However, why would this matter? Of all the games, a 2D Worms game is the last one that needs to be in 1080p and 60fps. There are also new audio and sound effects, which, as a fan of the original release in 2001, I really appreciate.

This is the same game that shipped in 2001, with 1080p gameplay and new audio. However, despite the false advertising, I'm still inclined to give this a positive review. This is because this is a working version of Worms World Party for modern operating systems--the old 2001 'Sold Out' version, which I still own a physical copy of, no longer works with Windows 7, nevermind Windows 10 which I recently upgraded to. I have been longing to play Worms World Party again for many years, so I am thrilled to be able to do that again.

So in short, if you don't care about the false advertising and, like me, just want to play LAN or Local games of Worms World Party for nostalgic value or fun, pick it up. It was my first Worms game, and has always been my favourite, due to the amount of fond memories I have of it :)

reviewText:
I'm surprised to see so many negative reviews, so here's some counterbalance.

It's still the same adictive game that we've grown so fond of, with excellent gameplay. However, there are some things you'll wish to consider:
This is still Worms world Party, so if you already own this game, you're not gaining a lot by buying this version. all you get is native 1080p in the matches and some fancy new sound effects.

About these soundeffects: I'm very gratefull that Team17 gives you the option whether to use these new effects, or stick with the classic set. While I respect the effort they put into the new  effects, they just sound too overdone for my taste.

If you have Worms Armageddon, there's a few different consideration. WWPR, just like the original WWP, added the Wormpot feature: 3 slots where you can set additional rules/features. such as red blood graphics or earthquakes between each turn. Be advised, however, that hosting from behind a router is less easily setup compared to W:A. WWP doesn't have the Hostbuddy system. So if you want to host, you'll have to portforward (there's a guide on here already which worked for me)

Performance: NO, WWPR does not yet perform at the promised 60fps for me (I get 40 to 50 with R9-270x). For me, even if this doesn't end up being fixed, the gameplay is smooth enough and there's no need to worry about it. So if this is your only fear about buying this game, I would suggest you just try it. Either it works and you'll have one hell of a blast, or you can easily get a refund from steam.
